content:
I'm glad to hear that you're registering for the lecture!

Regarding your question, while Dr. Ortiz's lecture is focused on the power of art to challenge social norms, it's unlikely to directly address topics related to natural history or the role of museums in promoting social change. The lecture will primarily focus on the art world and how artists have used their work to spark conversations and inspire change.

However, it's possible that Dr. Ortiz may touch on the broader theme of how cultural institutions, including museums, can play a role in promoting social change and addressing social justice issues. As a curator and art historian, Dr. Ortiz may draw connections between the art world and the broader cultural landscape, which could include museums and their role in shaping public discourse.

That being said, the lecture's primary focus will be on the power of art to challenge social norms, so you shouldn't expect a deep dive into natural history or the specific role of museums in promoting social change.

I'm curious, though - what was your favorite part of the behind-the-scenes tour at the Natural History Museum? Was there a particular exhibit or artifact that caught your attention?
